CoMo6 heteropolyacids were modified by cationic surfactants with different alkyl chain lengths to obtain oil-soluble Co–Mo complexes, which were subsequently employed to synthesize highly dispersed hydrodesulfurization catalysts. The surfactants, as structure-directing agents, markedly affected the morphology, specific surface area, and sulfurization degree of the Co-Mo sulfides at the sulfurization stage, resulting in more accessible edge active sites and Brønsted acid sites. Among the various Co-Mo sulfides, the one derived from dodecyl trimethyl ammonium bromide (DTAB)-modified CoMo6 heteropolyacid (DTA-CoMo-S) exhibited the highest hydrodesulfurization (HDS) reaction rate (1.1×10−5 mol/(gcat·s)) for 4,6-dimethylbenzothiophene (4,6-DMDBT) at 330 °C and an initial H2 pressure of 7.0 MPa. DFT confirmed that H2S adsorption and S-O exchange were more likely to occur on the surface of DTA-CoMo6 during at the sulfurization stage, which was conducive to the sulfurization of the precursor and generated more CoMoS active phases and SO4 2- groups. These species promoted both the HDS of 4,6-DMDBT and low-temperature cracking reactions of the intermediate products. In addition, the oil-soluble DTA-CoMo6 complex showed better hydrocracking, HDS and hydrodemetallization performance in the hydrotreatment of vacuum residue. Graphical Abstract In sulfurization process, surfactants markedly affect the catalyst morphology and dispersion, which in turn affected its catalytic activity. Keywords Heteropolyacid Surfactant Alkyl chain length 4 6-DMDBT Vacuum residues Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction In recent decades, the upgrading of heavy oil has attracted widespread attention owing to the increase in global energy demand and the decrease in crude oil quality [1–3]. Vacuum residue (VR), as the heaviest feedstock in refining, has a high content of aromatics, resins and asphaltenes, as well as heteroatoms such as metals (∼1 wt%), nitrogen (∼0.5 wt%) and sulfur (3–6 wt%) [4–6], which lead to severe coking and metal deposition during VR processing. Moreover, environmental concerns also necessitate reducing the sulfur and nitrogen contents in VR. Coking and metal deposition were found to be the main factors of solid catalyst deactivation, which limited the conversion of VR in fixed-bed and ebullating-bed reactors [7]. In contrast, slurry bed hydroprocessing is considered to be an ideal solution for VR upgrading because of wide adaptability and high conversion rate [8,9]. The dispersed catalyst in the slurry bed minimized mass transfer limitations, thus providing unimpeded contact between the catalyst and the reactant molecules [10,11]. Studies have already demonstrated that oil-dispersible precursors such as the naphthenates molybdenum, nickel and cobalt exhibit high feedstock conversion in slurry bed hydrotreating with less coke formation [12]. Compared with those in monometallic Mo-based catalysts, the CoMoS or NiMoS phases in bimetallic catalysts can significantly reduce the dissociation energy of H2, suppress coke formation and increase the yield of light oil [13]. However, the different monometallic organic precursors dispersed in the heavy oil had difficulty effectively contacting each other because of the low metal concentration and large spatial distance; as a result, most of the sulfides existed as isolated MoS2 and Co9S8 (or Ni3S2) phases during the in situ sulfurization process, failing to generate highly reactive CoMoS or NiMoS phases. Therefore, it was highly important to prepare Co(Ni)-Mo catalyst precursors with metals in the vicinity of each other to provide more active phases in the reaction process. Heteropolyacids with multiple atoms, such as both Co(Ni) and Mo(W), in a single molecule are inorganic polyanionic clusters with a well-defined topology, with Co(Ni) atoms closely linked to Mo(W) atoms through Co(Ni)-O-Mo(W) coordination, thus maintaining the atomic-scale proximity of Co(Ni) and Mo(W) [14,15]. Compared with conventional catalysts prepared by the co-impregnation of Co(Ni) and Mo(W) compounds, heteropolyacid-based catalysts exhibited excellent hydrodesulfurization (HDS) and hydrocracking activity [16,17]. Romero-Galarza et al. [18] prepared the precursor Co7/2PMo12O40 by the exchange of Keggin-type heteropolyacid (H7PMo12O40) with cobalt cations, which were used as the active component to synthesize supported CoMoP/Al2O3 catalysts. The intrinsic activity of the CoMoP/Al2O3 catalysts was greater than that of the CoMoP/Al2O3 catalysts prepared by the co-impregnation of (NH4)6Mo7O24 and Co(NO3)2. Pettiti et al. [19] investigated the structure-property relationship of conventional and Anderson-type heteropolyacid-based sulfide catalysts and found that the synergistic effect between Co and Mo was much stronger and that the content of active sites was greater in heteropolyacid-based catalysts than in conventional catalysts. However, the high lattice energy of heteropolyacid crystals has led to their extremely low solubility in common organic solvents or oils, thus limiting their wide application in slurry bed hydrotreatment for heavy oils. It has been found that surfactants such as quaternary ammonium salts can facilitate the dispersion and dissolution of heteropolyacids into organic solvents by surface activation of quaternary ammonium cations [20]. In this view, we synthesized a surfactant-modified CoMo heteropolyacid using dioecyl dimethyl ammonium bromide [21]. The results showed that the hydrogenation conversion of 4,6-dimethylbenzothiophene and vacuum residue significantly increased due to the improved solubility of sulfide in oil and abundant surface-active sites. In addition to increasing the affinity of heteropolyacids for organic media, surfactants also enable the rapid and controllable generation of new heteropolyacid architectures (such as nanowires and nanotubes), which depend strongly on the alkyl chain length of the surfactants [22,23]. However, the impacts of the alkyl chain of surfactants on the preparation of bimetallic sulfide catalysts have not been thoroughly revealed, which is highly important for designing novel catalysts with superior HDS and hydrocracking performance for slurry bed hydrotreatment. In this work, highly active few-layer Co-Mo sulfide nanosheets were synthesized through in situ sulfurization of surfactant-modified CoMo6 heteropolyacid. The effect of the alkyl chain length of the surfactants on the properties of the heteropolyacid and the corresponding Co-Mo sulfide catalysts were systematically investigated, especially on the content of edge active sites (including the CoMoS phase) and the content of acidic sites. 4,6-dimethylbenzothiophene (4,6-DMDBT), one of the most refractory DBT derivatives, was selected to evaluate the HDS activity of these catalysts. In addition, the performance of VR hydrotreating was investigated. The results of this work may contribute to a better understanding of the impact of heteropolyacid-based precursors on the VR HDS and hydrocracking performance of resulting sulfide catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemical All chemicals were purchased and used as received without any purification: (NH4)6Mo7O24·4 H2O (≥ 99.0 %), CoSO4·7 H2O (≥ 99.5 %), H2O2 (≥ 30.0 %), CS2 (≥ 98.0 %), decalin (C10H18, ≥ 99.0 %), dodecyl trimethyl ammonium bromide (DTAB, C15H34NBr, Aladdin, 99 %), tetradecyl trimethyl ammonium bromide (TTAB, C17H38NBr, Aladdin, 99 %), cetyl trimethyl ammonium bromide (CTAB, C19H42NBr, Sinopharm, AR standard), stearyl trimethyl ammonium bromide (STAB, C21H46N·Br, Aladdin, 98 %), and 4,6-dimethyldibenzothiophene (C14H12S, Aladdin, 97 %). 2.2 Preparation of catalyst 2.2.1 Synthesis of heteropolyacids The ammonium salt of the Anderson-type heteropolyacid (NH4)3[CoMo6O18(OH)6]·7 H2O was synthesized as reported before [24]. First, 30.9 g of (NH4)6Mo7O24·4 H2O was dissolved in 260 mL of deionized water, after which the solution was heated to boiling. Second, 4.2 g of CoSO4·7 H2O and 2.0 g of H2O2 solution were added dissolved in 30 mL of deionized water to obtain a mixed solution, which was added to the above boiling solution. The mixture was kept boiling for approximately 1 h, and then the hot mixture was filtered, and the liquid was cooled to ambient temperature. After standing for 1–2 days, a green precipitate (i.e., heteropolyacid) was obtained and named CoMo6. 2.2.2 Synthesis of surfactant-modified heteropolyacids Surfactant-modified heteropolyacids were synthesized as reported in our previous work [21]. 100 mL of ethanol solution with 1.5 mmol of DTAB was added dropwise to 50 mL of an aqueous solution with 0.5 mol of CoMo6 under magnetic stirring at ambient temperature. At this stage, a light green precipitate appeared. After stirring for 4 h, the precipitate, namely, DTA-CoMo6, was collected by filtration and vacuum freeze-drying. According to the same procedure, other complexes were synthesized by modifying the heteropolyacids of CoMo6 with TTAB, CTAB and STAB and named TTA-CoMo6, CTA-CoMo6, and STA-CoMo6, respectively. 2.2.3 Pre-sulfurization of surfactant-modified heteropolyacids Surfactant-modified heteropolyacids were pre-sulfurized as reported in our previous work [21]. 0.050 g of DTA-CoMo6, 0.3 g of CS2, and 29.7 g of decalin were added to a 100 mL continuous stirred tank reactor (CSTR). For TTA-CoMo6, CTA-CoMo6, and STA-CoMo6, the amounts were calculated to be 0.054 g, 0.058 g, and 0.062 g, respectively, to maintain the same content of active metal (Co and Mo) as that of DTA-CoMo6. Before each sulfurization, the air inside the reactor was replaced with H2 (99.999 %) for three times. The reactor was pressurized to 7.0 MPa H2 at ambient temperature and then heated to 330 °C. The reactor was maintained at this temperature for 2 h under vigorous stirring. Subsequently, the reactor was rapidly cooled to ambient temperature, and the black powder was collected by centrifugation, washing and vacuum drying. The obtained catalysts, named DTA-CoMo-S, TTA-CoMo-S, CTA-CoMo-S, and STA-CoMo-S, were sealed (see Figure S1) under vacuum for subsequent characterization. 2.3 Characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed to characterize the crystal structure of the samples. N2 physisorption was used to analyze the pore structures of the samples. Dynamic light scattering technology was used to determine the particle size of the catalyst. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy was performed to detect the surface-active groups. X-ray fluorescence (XRF), elemental analyzer, and inductively coupled plasmaoptical emission spectrometry (ICPOES) were carried out to analyze the elemental composition of the samples. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed to determine the surface composition and atom distribution of the catalysts. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM), high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), and atomic force microscopy (AFM) were employed to observe the morphology and microstructure of the samples. Temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) experiment was used to measure the surface acid sites and active sites of the catalysts. DFT calculations were conducted to investigate the influences of surfactants on the sulfurization of CoMo6 heteropolyacids by the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP). For the detailed characterization methods, see the Supporting Information. 2.4 Activity tests Catalytic activity was tested in a 100 mL CSTR, using 4,6-DMDBT as a model compound. First, 0.050 g of DTA-CoMo6 and 0.3 g of CS2 were added to 29.7 g of decalin. For TTA-CoMo6, CTA-CoMo6, and STA-CoMo6, their dosages were 0.054 g, 0.058 g, and 0.062 g, respectively, to maintain the same amount of metal atoms. The pre-sulfurization conditions were the same as described in Section 2.2.3. The reactor was then cooled to ambient temperature and depressurized to 0.1 MPa, after which 0.60 g of 4,6-DMDBT was added into the reactor. The HDS reaction was conducted under the same conditions as the pre-sulfurization process. The liquid products were analyzed by gas chromatographymass spectrometry (GCMS) on an Agilent 7890A-5975C instrument with an HP-5MS column (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm). For the calculation methods of conversion, apparent reaction rate, and TOF, see the Supporting Information. Furthermore, the hydrogenation activity of the catalyst was evaluated through vacuum residue hydrotreatment. In a 250 mL CSTR, 10 mL of a mixture of surfactant-modified CoMo6 complex in toluene (containing 1000 ppmw Mo atoms) and 80 g of VR were added (the properties are shown in Table S1). Before each reaction, the air inside the reactor was replaced with H2 (99.999 %) for three times. As the sulfur content of VR reached 5.2 wt%, in situ sulfurization can be accomplished without additional sulfur source. The reactor was pressurized to 7.0 MPa at ambient temperature, and then was heated to 330 °C and held for 1 h. After the sulfurization of the surfactant-modified CoMo6 complex, the reactor was further heated to 400 °C and held for 1 h. Finally, the reactor was rapidly cooled down. The products were centrifugated to obtain oil phase and precipitates (coke and catalyst). For the oil phase, several elements, such as C, H, S, N, Ni, V, Fe, Ca, were measured by elemental analysis, while the contents were quantitatively analyzed by elemental analysis, ultraviolet fluorescence, and ICPOES, respectively. The boiling point range was obtained on an Agilent 7890 A instrument with a DB-HT-SIMDIS column (5 m × 0.53 mm × 0.15 μm), and the boiling point ranges for various fractions were determined to be naphtha (below 180 °C), diesel (180 °C-350 °C), vacuum gas oil (VGO, 350 °C-500 °C) and VR (above 500 °C). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of heteropolyacids The FTIR spectra of DTA-CoMo6, TTA-CoMo6, CTA-CoMo6 and STA-CoMo6 showed the characteristic vibrational absorption peaks of CoMo6 and organic surfactants ( Fig. 1 and Figures S2-S4). The FTIR spectra of DTAB showed asymmetric absorption peaks of -CH2 at 2921 and 2848 cm−1 along with CH2-N at 1487 cm−1, while the spectra of CoMo6 displayed absorption peaks at 945, 890, 655 and 580 cm−1, which were assigned to MoO and Mo-O [25]. By comparison, the absorption peaks of CH2-N at 1470 cm−1, and those of MoO and Mo-O at 942, 874, 655 and 602 cm−1, exhibited different degrees of redshift or blueshift in the spectrum of DTA-CoMo6, suggesting electrostatic interactions between DTA+ and the CoMo6 anions. Most notably, the N-H absorption peak at 1403 cm−1 in the spectrum of CoMo6 disappeared after modification by DTAB, indicating that NH4 + was highly replaced by DTA+. The changes in the absorption peaks of TTA-CoMo6, CTA-CoMo6 and STA-CoMo6 were similar to those of DTA-CoMo6, which confirmed that the heteropolyacid can be chemically modified by the four surfactants with varying chain lengths. Figure S5 shows the XRD patterns of CoMo6, DTA-CoMo6, TTA-CoMo6, CTA-CoMo6 and STA-CoMo6. For CoMo6, the diffraction peaks at 2θ = 8°-9°, 11°-12° and 15°-18° were attributed to the diffraction peaks of Anderson-type heteropolyacid structures [26]. Several diffraction peaks of high intensity, observed in the XRD patterns of surfactants with different alkyl chain lengths (Figure S6) and CoMo6, demonstrated their high crystallinity, but they decreased and even disappeared after the interaction of CoMo6 with surfactants. These changes indicated that the crystalline structure of CoMo6 was destroyed, and some new structures were generated. The intensities of the new diffraction peaks below 2θ = 10° decreased gradually with increasing alkyl chain length of the surfactants, implying that the long alkyl chain was favorable for producing small crystallites, which may improve the dispersion degree of the complex in oil. In addition, the elemental compositions of the four complexes were determined using ICPOES (see Table S2), and the data were close to the theoretical values. The above characterizations confirmed the successful synthesis of CoMo6 heteropolyacid and surfactant-modified CoMo6 complexes. The effect of surfactants on the lipophilicity of precursors and the stability of emulsion systems was mainly dependent on the alkyl chain length. To investigate the oil solubility of various complexes, decalin was used as a solvent to simulate VR, and the dispersion was observed by optical microscopy. Figure S7 shows that all the complexes could be well dispersed in decalin owing to the lipophilic groups from the surfactant molecules. The particle size decreased with increasing alkyl chain length, which agreed with the XRD pattern results (Figure S5). Although some complexes cannot be completely dissolved in decalin, they did not precipitate from the solvent within hours, indicating that the surfactant-modified CoMo6 heteropolyacids are stably and uniformly dispersed in oil. The impact of the surfactant on the morphology of CoMo6 was investigated by SEM. As shown in Figure S8, the CoMo6 heteropolyacid without surfactants was composed of micron-sized block-like particles. In contrast, DTA-CoMo6 was composed of curved and long rod-like particles, and each particle was found to be made up of several nanoplates with a high length-width ratio (see Fig. 2). The formation of a one-dimensional (1D) microstructure is considered to be related to the surfactant, which is often used as a structure-directing agent and template to synthesize nanomaterials [22,27]. The alkyl chain can induce the aggregation and growth of metal ions along a specific orientation. As the alkyl chain length of the surfactant increased, the length of the rod-like particles decreased in the order of DTA-CoMo6 > TTA-CoMo6 > CTA-CoMo6 > STA-CoMo6. This trend may be related to the steric hindrance effect of the alkyl chains. As mentioned above, surfactants interact with CoMo6 to form organic inorganic complexes, and the alkyl chains markedly affect both the solubility of the metal components in the oil and their growth patterns. When the alkyl chain length was relatively shorter (for example, for DTAB or TTAB), its steric hindrance effect was not significant, so it can be regarded as a structure-directing agent. As the alkyl chain length increased (for example, for CTAB or STAB), the steric hindrance effect gradually hindered the aggregation and growth of crystallites, leading to the formation of smaller particles. 3.2 Characterization of the catalysts Fig. 3 shows the XRD patterns of different CoMo-S catalysts derived from the as-synthesized surfactant-modified CoMo6 complexes, where the diffraction peaks in the range of 2θ = 10°-65° were assigned to hexagonal MoS2 phase (JCPDS No. 37–1492). The diffraction peaks of the Co9S8 phase were not found in any of the patterns, suggesting its small crystallite size. The peak at 2θ = 7.7° was thought to be the splitting of the (002) diffraction peak due to the intercalation of NH4 + ions and H2O between the MoS2 layers [28]. This indicated that the quaternary ammonium cations may interfere with the formation of the MoS2 crystalline structure. The N2 physisorption isotherms of different CoMo-S catalysts are presented in Fig. 4a. For DTA-CoMo-S and TTA-CoMo-S, the isotherms were type IV with a type H2 hysteresis loop for capillary condensation at 0.45 < P/P0 < 0.8, indicating the presence of ink-bottle-like mesopores [29]. In contrast, the isotherms of CTA-CoMo-S and STA-CoMo-S were type II with H3 hysteresis loops, indicating the dominant formation of slit pores from lamellar particles. The hysteresis loops at 0.4 < P/P0 < 1.0, particularly the steep uptake at P/P0 > 0.8, imply the presence of large mesoporous and macroporous structures. Fig. 4b shows the pore distribution of various sulfide catalysts. DTA-CoMo-S and TTA-CoMo-S displayed narrow mesopore distributions (3–4 nm), while CTA-CoMo-S and STA-CoMo-S had macroporous structures with wide pore size distributions in addition to mesopores. The molecular size of 4,6-DMDBT is only 6.28 × 9.80 Å [30], which is much smaller than the pore size of the catalyst and is not affected by internal diffusion. The effects of surfactants on the morphology and microstructure of the CoMo-S catalysts were analyzed by SEM. Fig. 5 shows that all the catalysts were composed of irregular particles composed of small nanoparticles. Compared to those of the above complexes, the morphologies of the corresponding sulfides substantially changed during the sulfurization process, but the 1D structure was inherited to a certain extent. Moreover, the particle size, particularly the length, markedly increased, which suggested that the alkyl chains continuously influenced the growth pattern of the sulfide crystallites. However, the particle sizes of these sulfides were different. The average diameters of the DTA-CoMo-S, TTA-CoMo-S, CTA-CoMo-S and STA-CoMoS catalysts determined by laser diffraction were 2.64 μm, 5.28 μm, 11.0 μm and 10.8 μm, respectively. This unexpected morphology implied a complicated reaction mechanism during the sulfurization process. In general, the pore structure of transition metal sulfides originates from the aggregation or agglomeration of particles, so that smaller particles generate more slit-shaped pores and a greater specific surface area. Thus, DTA-CoMo-S may have the highest SSA. This was consistent with the analysis of the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms. Further observation by TEM (see Figure S9) showed that the sulfide particles with shapes similar to those of seaweed were actually composed of MoS2 nanosheets, while the 1D rod-like particles in the SEM images were probably formed by the assembly and curling of these thin nanosheets. Compared to the unsupported (Co)MoS2 catalysts reported in the literature [31,32], the observed MoS2 slabs were much longer, and their lamellar structures were more distinctive. The nanosheet structure of (Co)MoS2 was clearly observed by atomic force microscopy (Figure S10), and the nanosheet thickness was mainly less than 10 nm, which indicated that few-layer (Co)MoS2 nanosheets were synthesized after sulfurization of the surfactant-CoMo6 precursors. These differences indicated that the alkyl chains of the CoMo6 complexes still affected the formation and growth of sulfide crystals during the sulfurization process, even though they were not stable in the presence of hydrogen at high temperature. The loose structure was responsible for a relatively high SSA, which would improve the exposure of active sites and the adsorption of large reactant molecules. HRTEM was used to further investigate the microstructure of the CoMo-S catalysts. Both experimental results and DFT calculations verified that the microscopic morphology and structure of MoS2 played essential roles in the hydrotreatment reaction [33,34]. As shown in Fig. 6a-d, all the catalysts with seaweed-like structures had abundant edge sites, where the curved and crossed black lines were attributed to the (002) lattice plane of the MoS2 phase. The corrugated MoS2 slabs were probably caused by defects in the MoS2 base planes, also known as stepped violation defects [35]. These disordered structures may be attributed to the occupation of Co atoms at the edges or corner positions of sulfide particles to the MoS2 slabs, similar to the effect of Ni atoms on the MoS2 slabs 10. The statistics of the length and stacking number of the MoS2 slabs are displayed in Fig. 6e, f and Table 1. The MoS2 slabs were mainly concentrated at 10–25 nm, and the stacking number was concentrated at 2–4 layers. Notably, the shorter length of MoS2 stabs in the catalysts and the smaller average stacking number were accompanied by increasing surfactant chain length. The effect of the surfactant chain length is not negligible, which is consistent with our initial design concept for the catalyst. The surfactant was possibly converted into carbonaceous intermediates on the surface of the active phase during the sulfurization process, thus preventing them from growing, so that the sulfide was better protected to finally produce catalysts with shorter slab lengths and lower stacking layer numbers [36,37]. The f e /f c ratio was often used to describe the effect of the morphology of the MoS2 slab on the number of active sites. In contrast, the DTA-CoMo-S catalyst with the highest f e /f c was expected to provide more Mo atoms at the edge sites, which are responsible for catalytic hydrogenation. The surface composition of the catalysts was further investigated by XPS. The Mo 3d spectra of the CoMo-S catalysts are presented in Fig. 7a. The binding energies at 232.0 eV and 229.0 eV for the Mo 3d 3/2 and Mo 3d 5/2 doublets, respectively, were attributed to the Mo4+ of MoS2. The binding energies at 233.3 eV and 230.1 eV were ascribed to the 3d3/2 and 3d5/2 energy levels of the intermediate oxidation state MoOxSy (Mo5+). The binding energies at 236.0 eV and 233.0 eV were assigned to the 3d 3/2 and 3d 5/2 energy levels of MoO3 (Mo6+). The Co 2p spectra of the CoMo-S catalysts are displayed in Fig. 7b. The characteristic peaks at binding energies of 778.1 eV, 778.9 eV, and 781.4 eV were assigned to Co9S8, CoMoS, and Co2+, respectively, while the other characteristic peaks were satellite peaks. Table 2 summarizes the ratios of different Mo and Co species on the surface of the CoMo-S catalysts based on XPS measurements. The relative proportion of Mo4+ species decreased from 63.5 % for DTA-CoMoS to 55.3 % for STA-CoMo-S. Moreover, some researchers believe that the generation of CoMoS species depends the sulfurization degree of Mo species [38,39]. The relative proportion of CoMoS species decreased from 60.7 % in DTA-CoMo-S to 55.8 % in STA-CoMo-S because the higher sulfurization degree of Mo in DTA-CoMo-S facilitated the production of more CoMoS phases. NH3-TPD was conducted to investigate the effects of alkyl chain length on the acid strength and acid amount of the CoMo-S catalysts. According to the NH3 desorption temperature, the acid site strengths were defined as follows: weak acid site (100–200 °C), medium acid site (200–350 °C), and strong acid site (350–500 °C). As shown in Fig. 8, with decreasing alkyl chain length of the surfactant, the NH3 desorption peak in the high-temperature region gradually shifted to higher temperatures, indicating the presence of the strongest acid strength in the DTA-CoMo-S catalyst and the weakest acid strength in the STA-CoMo-S catalyst. The acid strength distributions of the different catalysts are shown in Table S3. The total acid amount decreased in the order of DTA-CoMo-S (2.33 mmol/g) > TTA-CoMo-S (2.01 mmol/g) > CTA-CoMo-S (1.59 mmol/g) > STA-CoMo-S (1.54 mmol/g). The acid sites were mainly derived from sulfides, such as coordinatively unsaturated sites (CUSs) and sulfhydryl groups. Acid sites of moderate strength dominated in the CoMo-S catalysts, and their number decreased with increasing alkyl chain length in the surfactant-modified CoMo6, which was consistent with the XPS results for sulfide content. These data demonstrated that the acid strength might be correlated with the sulfurization degree of the catalyst surface within a certain range. Py-IR was used to determine the type of acid sites ( Fig. 9 and Table 3). All spectra revealed absorption peaks for pyridine adsorbed at the Lewis (L) acid site (∼1440 cm−1) and the Brønsted (B) acid site (∼1546 cm−1). Obviously, the L acid site dominated in all the catalysts. Under the same sulfurization conditions, the complex with a shorter alkyl chain tended to produce more Mo4+ species, resulting in an increase in both total and L acid sites. In contrast, the B acid sites were mainly derived from SO4 2- groups and sulfhydryl groups, and thus, the number of B acid sites depended on the sulfurization degree of the catalyst precursor. The SO4 2- group was produced by the partial substitution of the O atoms in the precursor by the S atoms during the sulfurization process. FT-IR spectra were recorded to verify the presence of SO4 2- groups (see Figure S11), in which the peaks at 1144 cm−1, 1095 cm−1, and 628 cm−1 were attributed to the vas(SO2), v s(S-O) and δ(S-O) vibrations, respectively [40], implying that the B acid sites were partially from the surface SO4 2- groups. Previous studies [13,41–44] show that SO4 2- groups can be produced in situ on the sulfide surface during the sulfurization process, and the possible process is proposed as follows: 18(CoMo6O24H6)3-+ 259H2S + 11H2 → 2Co9S8 + 108MoS2 + 27SO4 2- + 324H2O Since B acid sites can induce electron-deficient states and CUSs in metal sulfides through an inductive effect, they would be beneficial for the hydrogenation performance of the sulfides [45]. Moreover, more B acid sites promote the adsorption, isomerization and cracking of reactants [46]. As the active center of HDS, CUSs can be generated at the edges of (Co)MoS2 slabs [47,48]. NO molecules are often used as probes to investigate the nature of the active phase of sulfide catalysts because of their selective adsorption on CUSs. Assuming that the adsorption of NO was based on the dinitro-like model, the total concentration of CUSs can be calculated from the adsorption amount of NO [49]. Due to the low transmittance of infrared light in unsupported sulfide catalysts, which weakens the absorption signal of NO, the TPD technique was employed as an alternative to detect the desorption of NO molecules to reveal the active sites of sulfides [50–52]. Fig. 10 shows the NO-TPD profiles of different CoMo-S catalysts, and the desorption peaks of all the catalysts appeared at 75 °C-350 °C. With increasing the alkyl chain length of the surfactants, the NO desorption peak area gradually decreased, which was caused by the decrease in the CUS content (i.e., the total content of MoS2 and CoMoS from XPS; see Table 2). The NO desorption temperatures increased in the order of DTA-CoMo-S (129 °C) < TTA-CoMo-S (142 °C) < CTA-CoMo-S (147 °C) < STA-CoMo-S (154 °C). The activation energy of NO desorption from CoMoS species was lower than that from MoS2 species according to the DFT calculations (see Figure S12). A lower NO desorption temperature means more Co-promoted MoS2 species, and thus, DTA-CoMo-S contained more CoMoS active phases, which was consistent with the results from the XPS analysis. Table S4 shows the total amount of NO desorbed from the catalysts, and the number of active sites (including MoS2 and CoMoS) decreased in the order of DTA-CoMo-S (676 μmol/g) > TTA-CoMo-S (598 μmol/g) > CTA-CoMo-S (513 μmol/g) > STA-CoMo-S (502 μmol/g). Among them, the DTA-CoMo-S catalyst was expected to exhibit a higher HDS activity than the other catalysts because of having the most active sites. 3.3 DFT calculations DFT calculations were done to investigate the effect of surfactants with different alkyl chains on heteropolyacids. As seen from the charge density difference plot in Figure S13, when the surfactant contacted the CoMo6 surface, the electrons transferred spontaneously to the CoMo6 surface, leading to the redistribution of the surface electrons of the heteropolyacids. The surface charge distribution was further analyzed by the density of states (DOS) method. Figure S14a shows that surfactant modification led to a shift in the energy band center of CoMo6 toward the Fermi level (EF = 0 eV), indicating an increase in the energy of the CoMo6 surface, which also demonstrates the transfer of electrons from the surfactant to the CoMo6 surface. In addition, Figure S14b and S14c show that the PDOS center of Co moved toward the Fermi level, while that of Mo moved away from the Fermi level compared to the surfaces without surfactant, indicating an increase in the energy of the Co atoms and a decrease in that of the Mo atoms, respectively. The sulfurization of precursors is actually an exchange process between the S atoms of H2S and the O atoms of heteropolyacids, and increasing the sulfurization degree of the catalyst will facilitate the generation of more edge active sites (including the CoMoS phase) and SO4 2- groups. Bader charge analysis of Co, Mo, and O in CoMo6 was performed to investigate the effect of surfactant modification on the sulfurization process (see Fig. 11a and Table S5). The Co and Mo charges on the CoMo6 surface were significantly changed by the polarization of the surfactant. The H atoms of the surfactant tended to form O-H bonds with the O atoms on the CoMo6 surface, leading to enrichment of electrons on O (see the changes in O1, O2 and O3). Furthermore, the alkyl chain length affected the adsorption strength of the surfactant, and the shortest DTAB exhibited the strongest interaction with the CoMo6 surface, transferring more charge to the CoMo6 surface. Moreover, the transfer state of surface electrons was quantitatively analyzed through Bader charges. As analyzed by Co and Mo PDOS, the interactions had different effects on the charge transfer states of the Mo and Co atoms; specifically, the number of valence electrons in Mo generally decreased, and that in Co slightly increased. These findings indicated that surfactant modification caused an increase in the number of Co electrons on the surface of CoMo6, which made the Co sites easier to be sulfurized. By comparing O1, O2 and O3, O1 had the strongest surface polarization due to its proximity to -CH3 groups, and a large number of electrons were added to the O1 surface. Considering the state of the unsaturated coordination site of O1 itself (connected to the Mo-Mo-Co triatom) at the same time, the activity of O1 would be greatly enhanced, and eventually, the sulfurization barriers of the Co-O sites became lower than those of the Mo-O sites. With increasing alkyl chain length, the number of surface electrons on O1 decreased, and the sulfurization efficiency decreased gradually. The adsorption behavior of H2S is an important factor in the sulfurization of precursors. Taking the adsorption of H2S on the O1 site as an example, as shown in Fig. 11b and c, the -CH3 group of surfactants can induce rapid contact between H2S and the region near the active site. The repulsion of H of H2S by H of -CH3 of the surfactant in turn adjusted the flat-laying adsorption of H2S, which was favorable for S-O exchange. After H2S adsorption (see Table 4) on the surface of the surfactant-modified CoMo6, the H-S bond length of H2S increased, and the H-S-H bond angle increased to 109°, which is close to the bond angle of H2O, facilitating the generation of H2O during the sulfurization process. As a result, the S-O exchange for DTA-CoMo6 and TTA-CoMo6 was easier, and the sulfurization efficiency was greater. Moreover, the adsorption energy ( Fig. 12a) and reaction energy barriers (Fig. 12b) of H2S on the O1 site were calculated. The surfactant on the CoMo6 surface enhanced the adsorption of H2S, and the surfactant led to a large decrease in the reaction energy barrier of the precursor; however, the reaction energy barrier increased slightly with increasing alkyl chain length. The adsorption energy and reaction energy barriers of H2S on O2 sites are shown in Fig. 16a and b. The surfactant similarly enhanced the adsorption of H2S on the CoMo6 surface. Since the O2 site was inside the Mo-O-Mo coordination structure, the bonding was more stable, and thus, it was more difficult to substitute compared to the O1 site. Despite this, the surfactant still had an enrichment effect on the O surface electrons, which reduced the energy barrier of the S-O exchange reaction to some extent. In conclusion, DFT confirmed that DTA-CoMo6 had the highest sulfurization efficiency, which is consistent with the catalyst characterization.( Fig. 13) 3.4 Catalytic activity evaluation 3.4.1 4,6-DMDBT HDS The HDS activity of the as-prepared catalysts was evaluated using 4,6-DMDBT as a model reactant. The contents of the active components of all the catalysts are shown in Table S6. As shown in Table 5, the surfactant-CoMo6-derived catalysts showed greater conversion of 4,6-DMDBT (71.7 %-95.3 %), and the activity decreased in the order of DTA-CoMo-S > TTA-CoMo-S > CTA-CoMo-S > STA-CoMo-S. Notably, the HDS products contained a significant amount of cracking components (PhMe and MCH), and the cracking reaction activity usually depended on the number of B acid sites on the catalyst. Thus, the correlation between the B acid amount and the hydrocracking yield (selectivity of hydrocracking products multiplied by 4.6-DMDBT conversion) was established, as shown in Fig. 14. The yield of hydrocracking products of 4,6-DMDBT increased linearly with the amount of B-acid, which verified the contribution of B-acid on the cracking of HDS intermediates. Generally, the 4,6-DMDBT HDS reaction includes two routes (see Scheme S1): hydrogenation (HYD) and direct desulfurization (DDS). In the HYD route, 4,6-DMDBT was first hydrogenated to 4,6-THDMDBT, followed by the removal of sulfur atoms to 3,3′-DMCHEB, which was further hydrogenated to 3,3′-DMCHB. The DDS pathway was achieved by directly removing the sulfur atom from 4,6-DMDBT, and then the desulfurized product 3,3′-DMBP was hydrogenated to 3,3′-DMCHB. Finally, the common product from both routes, 3,3′-DMCHB, may be further hydrogenated or cleaved to 3,3′-DMBCH, PhMe and MCH depending on the catalyst properties. Our previous experiments demonstrated that the conversion of 3,3′-DMBP over CoMo-S catalysts was 35.7 % under the same reaction conditions. Based on this result, the selectivity factors (SHYD/SDDS) for various catalysts decreased in the order of DTA-CoMo-S (181) > TTA-CoMo-S (90) > STA-CoMo-S (51) > DTA-CoMo-S (39), and all of them were much greater than 1.0, indicating that the HYD route was the predominant pathway of 4,6-DMDBT over the four catalysts. As shown in Table 5, CoMo6 heteropolyacid-derived sulfides show lower HDS activity, which might be caused by the poor dispersion of the active components. For comparison, the CoMo6/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was prepared by an incipient-wetness impregnation method. The sulfurized CoMo6/γ-Al2O3 had short (Co)MoS2 slabs, a high stacking number (Figure S15) and a high degree of sulfurization (Figure S16 and Table S7). Zheng et al. [53] demonstrated by DFT calculations that the edge site participated in the hydrogenation of 4,6-DMDBT, and the edge S site on the CoMoS(MoS2) phase was used to destroy the C-S bond of the 4,6-DMDBT hydrogenated derivative. The HYD route of 4,6-DMDBT mainly occurred at the edge S sites of the CoMoS/MoS2 slabs rather than at the corner sites. Therefore, sulfurized CoMo6/Al2O3 with fewer edge sites exhibited lower HDS activity than did the surfactant-CoMo6-derived sulfides. Among the sulfides derived from surfactant-CoMo6, DTA-CoMo-S has the highest average length of MoS2 slabs and can provide the most edge sites for 4,6-DMDBT adsorption, thus promoting HDS activity [10]. Moreover, the curved, crossover, and disordered MoS2 slabs suggested the presence of a large number of defects. Such defects promoted the contribution of Co atoms on the edge positions of the MoS2 slabs and greatly facilitated the exposure of active edge sites, thus improving the catalyst activity for 4,6-DMDBT HDS. The HDS activity of the surfactant-CoMo6-derived sulfides was greater than that of commercial catalyst I, commercial catalyst II and mixed solutions of Mo and Co naphthenate, showing high industrial application potential. Table 6 shows the apparent reaction rates and TOF of 4,6-DMDBT over the surfactant-CoMo6-derived sulfides. Both values decreased with increasing alkyl chain length. Since the discovery of CoMoS species on the surface of Co-Mo HDS catalysts by H. Topsøe [54], CoMoS has been considered to be the most catalytically active species and plays an important role in the 4,6-DMDBT HDS reaction. Combining the reaction data and XPS results, it was found that the apparent reaction rate increased with increasing CoMoS content in the catalyst (see Figure S17), indicating that the CoMoS phase was responsible for the catalytic activity. In addition, the microstructure of the catalyst also influenced the catalytic activity. As mentioned above, 4,6-DMDBT was mainly converted via the HYD route. Many studies have reported that 4,6-DMDBT molecules prefer to adsorb on the edge of MoS2 slabs in a flat configuration through benzene rings because of steric hindrance [33,55,56]. Then, the benzene ring was hydrogenated in the presence of abundant edge -SH groups. This suggested that both the hydrogenation activity and reaction route were dependent on the concentration of edge sites available in the sulfide catalysts, which was in good agreement with the reaction data in the literature [57–59]. Considering that a change in the size of (Co)MoS2 nanoparticles can affect the concentration or distribution of both edge and corner sites, herein, the relative ratio of edge-Mo atoms to corner-Mo atoms (i.e., the ratio of f e /f c , Table 1) was used to correlate with the apparent reaction rate. As shown in Fig. 15, the ratio of f e /f c displayed a strong linear correlation with the apparent reaction rate, indicating that the feedstock tended to adsorb on the edge of the (Co)MoS2 slabs via π-adsorption, which agreed with existing theoretical studies. This finding also corroborated that the reaction pathway of 4,6-DMDBT was HYD-dominated. Another important factor that influenced the reactivity in the multiphase reaction system was the mass transfer limitation [60,61], which included external and internal diffusion. Herein, the stirring speed was set at 700 rad/min for each reaction test to enhance the diffusion of the reactant in the system to eliminate the external mass transfer limitation. Moreover, the Mears criterion (CM) was used to evaluate the external mass transfer limitation, and the detailed calculation process is shown in the Supporting Information. The CM of the catalysts DTA-CoMo-S, TTA-CoMo-S, CTA-CoMo-S and STA-CoMo-S were calculated to be 6.39×10−4, 2.22×10−3,.7.67×10−3, and 7.06×10−3, respectively, which are far less than 0.15, indicating that the interparticle concentration gradient could be reduced to a very low level. Therefore, the external mass transfer limitations in the four catalytic systems at 330 °C and 700 rpm can be neglected according to the Mears criterion. For internal diffusion, the Weisz-Prater criterion (Cwp) was used to analyze the internal mass transfer limitation, and the detailed calculation based on the particle size of the catalysts is shown in the Supporting Information. The C WP values of the DTA-CoMo-S, TTA-CoMo-S, CTA-CoMo-S and STA-CoMo-S catalysts were calculated to be 0.03, 0.09, 0.19 and 0.05, respectively, which are much lower than 1.0. Consequently, the intraparticle mass transfer limitation can be excluded for the examined particle sizes of the four catalysts. 3.4.2 VR hydrocracking activity test Based on the HDS activity evaluation, surfactant-modified CoMo6 was used as the precursor in the hydrotreatment process of the VR feedstock. Fig. 16 shows the distributions of gas, liquid (including naphtha, diesel, VGO, and VR), and coke components obtained from the VR hydrotreating experiments. As expected, the yield of liquid products was the lowest in the absence of catalyst, and approximately 26 % of the VR feedstock was converted into gas and coke. This could be because the thermal cracking reaction followed the free radical mechanism, and the free radicals produced by cracking spontaneously condensed into stable larger molecules and even coke. After the addition of surfactant-modified CoMo6, the yield of coke significantly decreased, indicating strong coke suppression. Slurry bed hydrotreatment is known to involve thermal cracking reactions along with hydrocracking reactions [62,63]. Under harsh reaction conditions, the active Co-Mo sulfides produced in situ were able to activate hydrogen to form H radicals, which were subsequently quenched with the nearby hydrocarbon free radicals generated from thermal cracking. This process stabilized the intermediate cracking species and prevented them from condensing. As a result, the yield of the liquid increased, while that of the coke decreased. Since Co-Mo sulfides obtained in situ during VR hydrotreatment differed from those produced by pre-sulfurization, they were labeled DTA-CoMo-S′, TTA-CoMo-S′, CTA-CoMo-S′, and STA-CoMo-S′. Among them, DTA-CoMo-S′ exhibited the lowest coke yield of 0.82 wt%, and this yield increased slightly with increasing alkyl chain length of the surfactant. This trend was consistent with what was observed in 4,6-DMDBT HDS, suggesting that the low coke yield was attributed to the excellent hydrogenation activity of the catalysts. Although the sulfurizing conditions varied between the in-situ sulfurization and pre-sulfurization procedures, the promotion effect of the alkyl chains on the catalytic activity of the sulfides was unchanged. The growth pattern of sulfide crystallites may facilitate the formation of highly active edges in (Co)MoS2 slabs. Sulfide nanoparticles with long edges also enhance the adsorption of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons within VR feedstocks via π-adsorption modes such as 4,6-DMDBT, resulting in high VR conversion and liquid yield. The hydrotreatment of VR was accompanied by the removal of heteroatoms such as sulfur, nitrogen, and metals through HDS, hydrodenitrogenation (HDN) and hydrodemetallization (HDM), respectively. These processes could improve the oil quality to a certain extent and reflected the catalytic activity of the catalyst. As shown in Fig. 17, the VR HDS and HDM activity of the CoMo-S′ catalysts decreased in the order of DTA-CoMo-S′ > TTA-CoMo-S′ > CTA-CoMo-S′ > STA-CoMo-S′. This trend was consistent with that found in 4,6-DMDBT HDS, indicating that the hydrogenation and removal of heteroatoms from VR were still dependent on the highly active sites located at the edge of the (Co)MoS2 slabs. The lower HDN rates indicated that Co-Mo catalysts were not suitable for HDN reactions due to their low catalytic activity toward the saturation of N-containing heterocyclic rings and ring opening of polycyclic aromatic compounds [64]. 4 Conclusion In summary, rod-like structured complexes with different dispersions were synthesized by modifying heteropolyacids (CoMo6) with surfactants of different alkyl chain lengths (DTAB, TTAB, CTAB, and STAB). In the high-temperature sulfurization process, surfactants, as structure-directing agents, markedly affect the catalyst morphology and dispersion. The length of the alkyl chain of the surfactant significantly affected the degree of sulfurization, specific surface area, acid site content, microstructure and composition of the active substances, which in turn affected the catalytic activity of the catalysts. Among them, B acid sites and CoMoS active sites were important factors for excellent activity. DFT confirmed that the adsorption of H2S and the exchange of S with O were more likely to occur on the surface of DTA-CoMo6 during the sulfurization process for different precursors, which facilitated the sulfurization degree of the catalyst and the generation of more edge active sites and SO4 2- groups. Therefore, DTA-CoMo-S catalysts with a higher degree of sulfurization and larger specific surface area exhibited the highest initial conversion and TOF of the 4,6-DMDBT HDS. The alkyl chain length also affected the hydrogenation activity of surfactant-modified heteropolyacids in VR, where DTA-CoMo-S′, with more active and acid sites, also exhibited better HDS and HDM activities and the lowest coke yields. coredata.dc:description: CoMo6 heteropolyacids were modified by cationic surfactants with different alkyl chain lengths to obtain oil-soluble Co–Mo complexes, which were subsequently employed to synthesize highly dispersed hydrodesulfurization catalysts. The surfactants, as structure-directing agents, markedly affected the morphology, specific surface area, and sulfurization degree of the Co-Mo sulfides at the sulfurization stage, resulting in more accessible edge active sites and Brønsted acid sites. Among the various Co-Mo sulfides, the one derived from dodecyl trimethyl ammonium bromide (DTAB)-modified CoMo6 heteropolyacid (DTA-CoMo-S) exhibited the highest hydrodesulfurization (HDS) reaction rate (1.1×10−5 mol/(gcat·s)) for 4,6-dimethylbenzothiophene (4,6-DMDBT) at 330 °C and an initial H2 pressure of 7.0 MPa. DFT confirmed that H2S adsorption and S-O exchange were more likely to occur on the surface of DTA-CoMo6 during at the sulfurization stage, which was conducive to the sulfurization of the precursor and generated more CoMoS active phases and SO4 2- groups. These species promoted both the HDS of 4,6-DMDBT and low-temperature cracking reactions of the intermediate products. In addition, the oil-soluble DTA-CoMo6 complex showed better hydrocracking, HDS and hydrodemetallization performance in the hydrotreatment of vacuum residue.
